titles.title: A Dataset for Metaphor Detection in Early Medieval Hebrew Poetry
FigureOut - Automatic Detection of Metaphors in Hebrew Across the Eras

descriptions.description: The corpus of late antique and medieval Hebrew is vast and represents a crucial linguistic and cultural bridge between Biblical and modern Hebrew. Poetry is prominent in texts from these time periods and one of its characteristics is the use of metaphor. Distinguishing figurative and literal words or phrases is a major task for scholars in the Humanities, especially in the fields of literature, linguistics, and hermeneutics. We present a new, challenging dataset of early medieval Hebrew poetry with expert annotations of metaphors with baseline results. The dataset contains 180 labeled texts, 7,000 sentences, and 45,000 words, with 15% of the words being metaphors. Inter-annotator agreement measured by Cohen's kappa is 0.618 (considered substantial).

Three language models were used: BEREL (pre-trained on 220 million words of medieval texts), AlephBERT (pre-trained on 2 billion words of modern Hebrew), and AlephBERT Adapted (trained on 2 billion words of modern Hebrew plus 10 million words of medieval texts from Project Ben-Yehuda and the Piyyut dataset). Fine-tuning for metaphor detection was performed using tokenizers with metaphor/not-a-metaphor classification. Language model adaptation involved training on additional prose and poetic medieval texts.

Poster presented at Digital Humanities 2023: Collaboration as Opportunity (DH2023), Graz, Austria, July 10-14, 2023. The poster introduces a new, challenging dataset in Hebrew and seeks to extend automatic metaphor detection capabilities in pre-modern Hebrew.
Project Ben-Yehuda is a volunteer-based online library of free Hebrew literature used as a source for medieval texts in the adapted language model training.

sections.sectionContent:
The corpus of late antique and medieval Hebrew is vast and represents a crucial linguistic and cultural bridge between Biblical and modern Hebrew. Poetry is prominent in texts from these time periods and one of its characteristics is the use of metaphor. Distinguishing figurative and literal words or phrases is a major task for scholars in the Humanities, especially in the fields of literature, linguistics, and hermeneutics. We present a new, challenging dataset of early medieval Hebrew poetry with expert annotations of metaphors with baseline results.

Image: A medieval Hebrew poem from the Worms Prayerbook, Germany, 13th Century, The National Library of Israel, "Ktiv" Project

• Early medieval Hebrew poems.
• 180 labeled texts, 7,000 sentences, 45,000 words.
• 15% of the words are metaphors.

Examples of Metaphors

| Hebrew | English | Meaning |
|--------|---------|----------|
| טבענו בגזרות, כשטופי ים | We drowned in decrees, like sea washed | There are too many decrees |
| הצית נשמה ויבער נר | Ignite a soul, fire a candle | Create a soul |
| עד דור עשירי לא עשו פרי | Until the tenth generation they did not bear fruit | For ten generations, they did no good deeds |

Inter Annotator Agreement

Inter-annotator agreement evaluates how consistently different annotators label data for NLP research (measured in Cohen's kappa). The score for our dataset is 0.618 (considered substantial).

Fine-tuning for metaphor detection

Process flow:
1. Pre-trained/Adapted Language Model
2. Tokenizer
3. Classification: Metaphor / Not a Metaphor

Example:
- Input: עיצבון במשלח ידינו
- Tokenized: עיצ_ _בון במשלח ידי_ _נו
- Output: Metaphor / Not a Metaphor labels

LM adaptation

Process flow:
1. Pre-trained Language Model
2. Masked language modeling
   - Input: עיצבון במשלח ידינו
   - Masked: עיצ_ <mask> בון <mask> ידי_ _נו
3. Tokenizer
4. Output: עיצבון במשלח ידינו

Language models (pre-trained & adapted)

Trained on additional prose and poetic medieval texts (Project Ben-Yehuda*) + Piyyut dataset

| Model | Data Size (words) | Data Type |
|-------|-------------------|------------|
| BEREL | 220 Million | Medieval |
| AlephBERT | 2 Billion | Modern |
| AlephBERT Adapted | 2 Billion + 10 Million | Modern + Medieval |

*Project Ben-Yehuda is a volunteer-based online library of free Hebrew literature.

• AlephBERT is outperformed by AlephBERT Adapted.
• BEREL, pre-trained on medieval texts, shows the best results.

f1 Score on test set

| Model | f1 Score |
|-------|----------|
| AlephBERT | 44.404 |
| BEREL | 48.3 |
| AlephBERT - adapted | 46.56 |

Chart shows BEREL achieving the highest f1 score of 48.3

Example case:

Hebrew text: ילד לניחוח חשקתיו

English: (A child for a scent - I have desired)

Expert explanation: The child is a non-metaphorical epithet for Isaac. "Scent" is a metonymic term for "sacrifice".

Model prediction: Berel (shown in blue box)

This example illustrates the complexity of metaphor detection in medieval Hebrew poetry, where cultural and religious context is crucial for accurate interpretation.
